term.name: pragmatism
term.source: From Greek pragmatikos: having to do with action, practical affairs, or matters of fact.
term.def: The view, originated by C.S. Peirce (1839–1914) and made famous by William James (1842–1910) and James Dewey (1859–1952), that the truth of a concept is to be evaluated by its practical consequences for human affairs.

A form of &consequentialism; that differs from &utilitarianism; by emphasizing practical action instead of usefulness to others. While pragmatism is thus a kind of &humanism;, it rejects &naturalism; and often tends to be a kind of &relativism;.
